titlestmt.titleproper: Eliot-Pearson Department of Child Development RecordsUA009

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-04-05 10:40:20 -0400.

repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

did.unittitle: Eliot-Pearson Department of Child Development Records

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into eleven series: Women's Education Association; Ruggles St. Nursery School and Nursery Training School of Boston; Board of Managers, Trustees, and Corporation records; Financial records; Annual and self-study report; Faculty meeting minutes and reports; Course materials; 2017 accessions; Office files; Audiovisual materials; and Student teacher files.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1996, the Eliot-Pearson Department of Child Studies became the Eliot-Pearson Department of Child Development. The department, already prominent in its field, grew between this date and the early 2010s in number of faculty members and lecturers, in courses offered, and in programs that serve students, researchers and families in the greater Boston area.

One landmark event that occurred during the period soon after the department's name change was the endowment of the Bergstrom Family Chair in Applied Developmental Science in 1997, which was described by Sol Gittleman in An Entrepreneurial University: The Transformation of Tufts 1976-2002 as "the nation's first professorship explicitly framed in ADS terms."

The department's facilities include the Eliot-Pearson Children's School, the Tufts Educational Day Care Center, and the Evelyn G. Pitcher Curriculum Lab. Students complement their course work with activities that take place in these facilities and, according to the course catalog for the academic year 2010-2011, with field work with children in a "wide range of applied settings, including schools, hospitals, clinics, day care centers, educational television studios, museums, and juvenile courts."

Undergraduates can choose either a major or a minor in Child Development. There are three Masters programs and a doctoral program in Applied Child Development. The catalog for 2000-2001 described ADS as "an emerging, interdisciplinary field that generates and uses theory and research about human development to improve the lives of children, youth, and families around the world." Students can follow a number of tracks throughout their education in Child Development, the three most common being preparation for a career in behavioral science, a career in human services, and a career in education. For those seeking the latter, the department offers a pre-K to 3 teacher certification program, and an elementary school teacher program in cooperation with the Department of Education. Another joint program is the M.A. in child and family policy, offered with the Department of Urban and Environmental Policy.

As of 2011, the department runs a number of research centers, institutes and special programs, including:Center for Applied Child Development Center for Reading and Language Research Child and Family WebGuide Developmental Technologies Research Group Healthy Families Evaluation Program Home-School Connection Program Institute for Applied Research in Youth Development. The International Adoption Project Tufts Adoption and Development Project
Information about these programs can be found on the department's website.

Every two years since 2001, the department, in partnership with the Communication and Media Studies Program, has presented the Eliot-Pearson Award for Excellence in Children's Media. These awards are nicknamed The Abbys, in honor of educator and co-founder Abigail Adams Eliot.
The Eliot-Pearson Department of Child Development's mission is "to contribute to a more just, caring and inclusive society."

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: All material accessioned prior to 1997 was originally arranged by subject, and no attempt was made to recreate original order. Material relating to administering the collection was removed to the documentation files of the collection in the archives.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: During processing of the first accessions, most of the newsclippings, photographs, press releases, and correspondence were separated from the subject files. These types of materials may still be found in later accessions of the subject files. When processing the second accession of material, several series were combined and one was moved to create its own collection.

Processing of the 2017 accessions was completed by Leah Edelman, Rose Koven, and Peter Lam in 2017. Materials were placed in archival boxes and oversize boxes if the orignal housing was damaged, and loose materials were placed in folders where needed. Received order was maintained. A box-level inventory and series-level description were created and the finding aid was updated at the time of processing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection is composed of administrative material including annual reports, correspondence, meeting minutes of the Board of Managers and the faculty, financial reports, and office files which document the development of the school from its association with the Women's Education Association, through its self-governance, to its eventual merger with Tufts University. Also included in the collection are Child Development student records; syllabi and course listings; audiovisual materials including photographs, slides, lantern slides, and videocassettes; licensure material for the department; and historic material about and kept by the department, including scrapbooks. The primary focus of this collection is the administrative records.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Copyright to all materials created by Tufts University employees in the course of their work is held by the Trustees of Tufts University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by the Eliot Pearson Department of Child Development, 2008-2017.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Eliot Pearson Department of Child Development Records, 1879-2015. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

controlaccess.subject: Curriculum and Instruction -- Academic Departments and Programs
Curriculum and Instruction -- Teaching Material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials relating to the Women's Education Association, out of which grew the Ruggles St. Nursery School and later, Eliot-Pearson.

did.unittitle: Ruggles St. Nursery School and Nursery Training School of Boston, records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains reports, articles, minutes, brochures, correspondence, and financial records associated with the Ruggles Street Nursery Training School, which became the Nursery Training School of Boston in 1926.

did.unittitle: Transfer of property to Nursery Training School
Board of Managers, Trustees and Corporation records
Board of managers and corporation records
Board of trustees, membership lists and correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of financial records of the Eliot Pearson School.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains annual reports from the director and members of the Advisory Board as well as a self-study report. The directors reports range from 1940-1962 and the Board member reports range from 1971-1991. Of particular interest is the Institutional Self-Study report which provides a cohesive picture of how the Eliot-Pearson Department meets the demands of its students and the field. Folders are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains faculty meeting minutes and reports. The majority of the material ranges from 1985-1997. Folders are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains brochures and catalogs from all periods in the history of the Eliot-Pearson Department of Child Development. These publications demonstrate the wide range of courses offered over the different incarnations of the Department. Also included are course outlines from 1943-1968 and syllabi from 1983-1996 which demonstrate the type of information being offered in the classroom during these different phases. Folders are arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Commentaries by Emelyn D. Osgood on Froebel's Mother Plays
Experiments in Free Play, Parts I-IV, L.B. Murphy, L.J. Stone, E. Lerner, E. Beyer, et al.

Workbooks contributed by Miss Susan Andrews from her work 1907-10 in the Fannie E. Smith Kindergarten Training School

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in received order.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list. This series may require review before it is available for use. Please contact DCA for further details.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by Eliot Pearson Department of Child Development, 2017, accession UA-2018-017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains syllabi and course listings; licensure material for the department; historic material about and kept by the department, including information about children in wartime; and scrapbooks of newsclippings and photographs about the Nursery Training School, the Ruggles Street Nursery School, and the Eliot Pearson School.

did.unittitle: Child Development 166-291 course syllabi; department course listings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes literature on children and families during wartime and other non-Eliot Pearson publications; information on the Tufts-Eliot Pearson merger; material about the Great Britain and Northern Ireland Nursery School, the World Organization for Early Childhood Education, and other non-Eliot Pearson organizations; as well as miscellaneous forms and correspondence.

did.unittitle: Nursery Training School, Ruggles Street Nursery School scrapbook and photographs
Nursery Training School, Eliot Pearson scrapbooks and photographs
Nursery Training School, Eliot Pearson scrapbooks and photgraphs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains information which documents the operations of the Ruggles Street Nursery through the present day administration of the Eliot-Pearson Department of Child Development. Included in the office files are reports, faculty files, and fundraising information. Included in this series are several folders containing information on Abigail Adams Eliot. These folders include some of her publications as well as her correspondence with members of the faculty both during her time at the school and after her retirement. Additionally there are several sets of correspondence which reflect the administration of the school. Folders are arranged alphabetically in two complete runs.

Curriculum issues eg. special tops 143 vs ind. study 140
This Bud's for you/alcohol and the media

U.S. National Committee for Childhood Education
White House Conference on Children and Youth

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes photographs, slides, and videocassettes documenting the classroom activities of the Eliot-Pearson Department of Child Development from its start as the Ruggles Street Nursery to its current incarnation. The majority of the photographs depict students working in the nursery school or in the classroom. The majority of the photographs are labeled as to which year they were taken but few have any people identified. Some of the photographs are cross-listed with the University Image collection. Also in the collection are public relation scrapbooks which contain newspaper clippings referencing the school. Folders are arranged chronologically. An attempt has been made to keep similar forms of media together.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Evelyn Pitcher, educator and chair of the Eliot-Pearson Department of Child Study and Human Development stands in front of the class.The person in the front row,third from the left with her hand up to her chest, was identified by Priscilla Harcourt to be her eldest sister Dr. Mary Ruth (Johns) Fox, MD. She led a distinguished career as a pediatrician for 25 years in the first HMO, Group Health, in Washington, DC.
